subject: RE: [junit] equals is "commutative" ... so
msgSnippet: Thomas, The contract for the equals method on class Object states that the method implements an equivalence relation:  ...It is symmetric: for any reference
messageBody:
Thomas,

The contract for the equals method on class Object states that the "method
implements an equivalence relation: ...It is symmetric: for any reference
values x and y, x.equals(y) should return true if and only if y.equals(x)
returns true...." The JUnit code is written according to the documented
contract of the equals method. Therefore, the burden lies on you to
implement an equals method that honors the contract.

Joshua Bloch, in his book, _Effective Java_, has explained very well how to
write a good implementation of the equals method. Furthermore, it is not
very difficult to write a good JUnit TestCase to ensure that your equals
implementation honors the contract. I have written my own TestCase for this
purpose, and the Junit-addons project (http://junit-addons.sourceforge.net/)
has a TestCase named EqualsHashCodeTestCase that you can extend.

Craig
